item.title: Does it Work and Why Does it Work?
item.description:
• Data Camp

Data Camp

This week please complete both the Introduction to R and Introduction to the Tidyverse courses on Data Camp. The modules cover an:

  • Intro to basics
  • Vectors
  • Matrices
  • Factors
  • Data frames
  • Lists
    and
  • Data wrangling
  • Data visualization
  • Grouping and summarizing
  • Types of visualizations

Please take your time with these modules. While the first gives you an understand of the R environment, the second deals with data wrangling, namely making sure data is “tidy”. We’ll be using this idea moving forward in the course.

item.title: 80% of Your Time with Data is Dedicated to Wrangling!
item.description:
• Data Camp
    • A Note About the Title

Data Camp

This week please complete both the Introduction to Data in R and Exploratory Data Analysis in R courses on Data Camp. The modules cover the:

  • Language of data
  • Study types and cautionary tales
  • Sampling strategies and experimental design
  • Case study (physical appearance of instructors and course evals)
    and
  • Exploring Categorical Data
  • Exploring Numerical Data
  • Numerical Summaries
  • Case Study (case study of email spam)

respectively.

A Note About the Title

That 80% figure is based on the Pareto Principal and is meant to be taken as a hyperbole. It roughly translates to the idea that 80 percent you time is spent simply finding, cleansing, and organizing data - aka wrangling - leaving only 20 percent for meaningful analyses.

item.description:

  • Data Camp

Correlation may Equal Causation

While we have head the same saying that correlation \(\nRightarrow\) causation, it CAN imply it (with enough evidence!) Watch this visualization of the concept below.

Data Camp

This week please complete both the Intermediate R1 and Foundations of Inference2 courses on Data Camp. The modules cover:

  • Conditionals and Control Flow
  • Loops
  • Functions
  • The apply family
  • Utilities
    and
  • Introduction to ideas of inference
  • Completing a randomization test: gender discrimination
  • Hypothesis testing errors: opportunity cost
  • Confidence intervals

  1. The Intermediate R module is a little heavy on the programming aspect so get an idea of what these functions do in general, but don’t spend too much time on any of the problems.↩︎

  2. Foundations of Inference assumed you have had some introduction to statistics at some point in your past. If you have not, please check out the Resources page for some suggestions on statistical reviews.↩︎
